definitions: eat, drink, or ingest food or drink
use up a resource such as time, energy, or fuel
examples: Americans consume too much processed food
The guests consumed all the appetizers quickly
This old car consumes a lot of gas
The project consumed most of our budget

definitions: succeed in dealing with a problem or difficulty and defeat it
be overwhelmed by a strong emotion to the point of losing control
examples: She overcame her fear of public speaking
They overcame many obstacles to succeed
He was overcome with grief at the funeral
Joy overcame her when she heard the news

definitions: have the courage to do something difficult, dangerous, or unpleasant
challenge someone to do something requiring courage
examples: I wouldn't dare speak to him that way
She dared to question the company policy
He dared me to jump off the diving board
I dare you to eat that hot pepper

definitions: unexpectedly experience or be faced with something difficult or hostile
examples: We encountered several problems during construction
She encountered an old friend at the store

definitions: wrap or coil something around a core or with itself
follow a twisting or spiral course
examples: Wind the rope around the post
She wound the bandage around his arm
The river winds through the valley
The path winds up the mountain

definitions: pick out and emphasize the most important parts of something
mark text with a bright color to make it stand out
examples: The report highlights the main problems
She highlighted the key achievements in her speech
Highlight the important passages in yellow
Students often highlight their textbooks

definitions: turn liquid into ice or another solid as a result of extreme cold
become suddenly motionless or paralyzed with fear or shock
examples: Water freezes at zero degrees Celsius
We need to freeze the leftovers
She froze when she saw the snake
Everyone froze at the sound of gunfire

definitions: try to reach an agreement or compromise by discussion with others
examples: They negotiated a new contract with the union
We need to negotiate better terms

definitions: kill someone unlawfully and with premeditation
examples: He was convicted of murdering his business partner
The detective investigates who murdered the victim

definitions: continue to have something or keep possession of it
keep someone in position or absorb and hold a substance
examples: She retained her maiden name after marriage
The company retained most of its employees
This fabric doesn't retain water
He retained a lawyer for the case

definitions: give evidence as a witness in a law court or provide proof
examples: She will testify against her former employer
Several witnesses testified to seeing the accident

definitions: be entitled to a particular benefit or privilege by fulfilling necessary conditions
make a statement less absolute by adding limitations or conditions
examples: You need experience to qualify for this job
She qualified for the Olympic team
I should qualify that statement
He qualified his remarks about the economy

definitions: focus one's attention or mental effort on a particular object or activity
increase the strength or proportion of a substance by removing water or diluting agents
examples: I can't concentrate with all this noise
Concentrate on finishing your homework
Boil the sauce to concentrate the flavors
The company concentrates juice for shipping

definitions: fasten or tighten with a screw by turning it
ruin or spoil something or cheat someone
examples: Screw the lid on tightly
He screwed the shelf to the wall
Don't screw up this opportunity
They really screwed me on that deal

definitions: go somewhere with someone as a companion or escort
play a musical accompaniment for a singer or another musician
examples: Her mother accompanied her to the interview
Security guards accompanied the celebrity
She accompanied him on the piano
I'll accompany your singing on guitar

definitions: provide a person or animal with shelter or lodging
contain or store something within a building or container
examples: The dormitory houses 200 students
We housed refugees during the crisis
The museum houses a valuable art collection
This building houses our main servers

definitions: keep or accumulate something for future use
examples: Store the leftovers in the refrigerator
Squirrels store nuts for the winter

definitions: cause someone to feel mild astonishment or shock by being unexpected
examples: The test results surprised everyone
Don't surprise me like that again

definitions: see an event, typically a crime or accident, take place
give evidence in a law court or sign a document as witness
examples: Several people witnessed the accident
I witnessed the entire argument
She witnessed at the trial
Can you witness this document for me

definitions: enter or record on an official list or directory
show a reading on a measuring instrument
examples: You need to register for classes
Please register your car with the state
The thermometer registered 100 degrees
His face registered surprise

definitions: strike lightly with a quick, sharp blow or series of blows
draw liquid through a tap or access a resource or supply
examples: She tapped him on the shoulder
Rain tapped against the window
They tapped the maple trees for syrup
We need to tap into new markets

definitions: feel or show approval or preference for someone or something
do something kind or helpful for someone
examples: Most voters favor the new policy
She favors her left leg when walking
Could you favor me with a reply
He favored us with a song

definitions: advertise or promote something to increase sales or public awareness
examples: They market their products to teenagers
The company markets organic food online

definitions: change the form, character, or function of something
change one's religious faith or other beliefs
examples: Convert the file to PDF format
They converted the garage into an office
He converted to Buddhism last year
She's trying to convert me to vegetarianism

definitions: make someone feel admiration and respect through one's qualities or actions
apply pressure to make a mark or design on a surface
examples: Her presentation really impressed the committee
He's always trying to impress people
The seal impressed a mark in the wax
They impressed the design onto the leather

definitions: become adjusted to new conditions or environment
make something suitable for a new use or purpose by modifying
examples: Plants adapt to their environment
It took time to adapt to the new culture
They adapted the novel for television
We need to adapt our strategy

definitions: change or cause to change in character or composition, typically in a small way
examples: She had to alter her wedding dress
Don't alter the original document

definitions: ask for food or money as charity, especially in the street
ask someone earnestly or humbly for something
examples: People beg for money at the station
The dog begs for food at dinner
I beg you to reconsider
She begged for forgiveness

definitions: inflict physical harm on something that impairs its value, usefulness, or normal function
examples: The storm damaged several buildings
Smoking damages your health

definitions: take and use something belonging to someone else with the intention of returning it
examples: Can I borrow your pen
She borrowed money from the bank

definitions: become twice as much or as many
have a dual purpose or function
examples: Sales doubled last year
Double the recipe for more guests
This room doubles as an office
She doubles as secretary and accountant

definitions: give intellectual, moral, and social instruction to someone, typically at a school
examples: We need to educate children about healthy eating
He was educated at private schools

definitions: expose someone or something valued to danger, harm, or loss
examples: Don't risk your life for money
She risked everything to start her business

definitions: cause great fear or nervousness in someone or something
examples: The loud noise scared the baby
Don't scare me like that

definitions: move one's hand to and fro in greeting or as a signal
move or cause to move in a smooth, undulating motion
examples: She waved goodbye from the window
Wave to get their attention
The flags waved in the breeze
Her hair waved naturally

definitions: go down below the surface of something, especially liquid
gradually decrease or decline in value, amount, quality, or strength
examples: The ship sank in deep water
My feet sank into the mud
Stock prices sank after the announcement
Her spirits sank when she heard the news

definitions: reduce something to a state of decay, collapse, or disintegration
examples: The flood ruined their home
Don't let one mistake ruin your life

definitions: keep or put something in a steady position so it does not fall
offset or compare the value of one thing with another
examples: She balanced the book on her head
It's hard to balance on one foot
We need to balance the budget
Balance work with family time

definitions: propel oneself through water by moving the limbs
examples: She swims every morning for exercise
Fish swim upstream to spawn

definitions: give shares of something or deliver to multiple recipients
examples: They distribute food to the homeless
The company distributes products worldwide

definitions: move along or out steadily and continuously in a current or stream
examples: Water flows downhill
Traffic flows smoothly on weekends

definitions: clean an area by brushing away dirt or litter
move swiftly and smoothly
examples: Please sweep the kitchen floor
She swept the leaves into a pile
The storm swept across the coast
He swept her into his arms

definitions: perform an activity or exercise repeatedly to improve proficiency
actively pursue or be engaged in a profession
examples: Practice the piano every day
The team practices on Tuesday evenings
She practices law in New York
He's been practicing medicine for years

definitions: cook food by dry heat without direct exposure to flame, typically in an oven
examples: Bake the cake for 30 minutes
She loves to bake bread on weekends

definitions: produce or provide a natural, agricultural, or industrial product
give way to arguments, demands, or pressure
examples: This farm yields excellent crops
The investment yields high returns
He refused to yield to their demands
Yield to oncoming traffic

definitions: put right an error or fault
mark the errors in written work
examples: Please correct your mistakes
She corrected his pronunciation
Teachers correct homework every night
I need to correct these test papers

definitions: make someone unhappy, disappointed, or worried
knock something over
examples: The bad news upset everyone
Don't upset yourself over small things
He upset the glass of water
The dog upset the trash can

definitions: win a victory over someone in a battle, game, or competition
examples: They defeated their rivals 3-1
No one can defeat the champion

definitions: see, notice, or recognize someone or something, especially suddenly or with difficulty
examples: I spotted her in the crowd
Can you spot the difference between these pictures

definitions: show or indicate the way to someone or direct the movement or positioning of something
examples: She guided tourists through the museum
Let your conscience guide your decision
